snippet: Men’s higher risk for heart disease may result in part from genetic variants on the one chromosome unique to men, researchers have found.
abstract: Maciej Tomaszewski publishes study in journal The Lancet describing Y chromosome variation that may explain why far more men than women die of heart disease; finds men with one genetic variant have a 50 percent increased risk of heart disease compared with men who have the opposite variant.
lead_paragraph: Men’s higher risk for heart disease may result in part from genetic variants on the one chromosome unique to men, researchers have found.

headline.seo: Heart Disease Risk May Be Tied to Y Chromosome
headline.main: Male Genes May Explain Higher Heart Disease Risk
headline.print_headline: Male Genes May Explain Higher Heart Disease Risk
